photo.title: Detail on Tour Saint Jacques

photo.description: The tower's rich decoration reflects the wealth of its patrons, the wholesale butchers of the nearby Les Halles market. The masons in charge were Jean de Felin, Julien MÃ©nart and Jean de Revier. It was built in 1509 to 1523, during the reign of King Francis I. With a dedication to Saint James the Great, the ancient church[2] and its landmark tower welcomed pilgrims setting out on the road that led to Tours and headed for the way of St James, which led to the major pilgrimage destination of Santiago de Compostela.

photo.title: Paris, Tour Saint Jacques

photo.description: Looking southwest, down Rue Dante and Rue Saint-Jacques from atop Notre-Dame's south tower. The sprawling, domed structure in the background is the UniversitÃ© de la Sorbonne Nouvelle, a.k.a. Paris III. Looks cutest when viewed large. See where this picture was taken. [?]
photo.tags: tiltshift faketiltshift paris blueroofs notredame france tower sorbonne lasorbonne parisiii ruedante ruesaintjacques geotagged geo:lat=48853184 geo:lon=2349175 travel europe frenchroofs parisianskyline fauxtiltshift photoshop
photo.title: Petite Paris, the Sorbonne

photo.description: La Tour Saint-Jacques is an early 16th century Gothic-style tower in the heart of Paris. It is all that remains from the church, Ã©glise Saint-Jacques de la Boucherie, which must have been a Gothic beauty if its bell tower is any indication. Although the church was demolished at the end of the 18th century, the tower was fortunately saved. It has become a symbol of this part of Paris, and in recent years underwent much needed restoration that returned it to its former glory (ended in 2008). The tower is surrounded by a beautifully landscaped park, known as Square de la Tour Saint-Jacques, which offers a respite from the busy streets around it.
photo.tags: paris france holiday canon spring march building french gothic
photo.title: Square de la Tour Saint-Jacques - (Day 17 Holiday 2011)

photo.description: Seen from Rue Nicolas Flamel. He was buried in the church the tower belonged to. The tower has a statue of Blaise Pascal, who is reputed to have done experiments with atmospheric pressure here. Plenty for the conspiracy/esoteric historian to play with. Flamboyant gothic - none of that staid perpendicular style!

photo.description: Tour Saint-Jacques (Saint-Jacques Tower) - Paris, France - 26 December 2010 This 52 meter (171 ft.) tall Gothic tower is all that remains of the former 16th century Church of Saint-Jacques-de-la-Boucherie (Saint James of the Butchery) which was leveled shortly after the French Revolution.

photo.title: 2010-12-26 France Vacation 1

photo.description: Built in 1523, this tower was originally part of the Church of Saint-Jacques-de-la-Boucherie, paid for by wealthy butchers and a part of the Way of St James, the Medieval route of pilgrimage to the Cathedral of Santiago de Compostela in Spain. The church was destroyed by revolutionaries in 1793, the tower remaining to allow it to be used as a shot tower to create bullets. Here, in 1648, Blaise Pascal, working with mercury, proved the existence of a vacuum and simultaneously created the barometer. Tour Saint-Jacques, 4th arrondissement, Paris, France
photo.tags: paris france ile de saintjacques tower 4th arrondissement
photo.title: Saint-Jacques Tower

photo.description: The Tour Saint-Jacques is all that remains of the former 16th century Church of Saint-Jacques-de-la-Boucherie that was leveled raised to the ground after the French Revolution. It was built between 1509 to 1523, during the reign of King Francis I. It marked a starting point for pilgrims to Tours.

photo.description: La Tour Saint-Jacques is an early 16th century Gothic-style tower in the heart of Paris. It is all that remains from the church, Ã©glise Saint-Jacques de la Boucherie, which must have been a Gothic beauty if its bell tower is any indication. Although the church was demolished at the end of the 18th century, the tower was fortunately saved. It has become a symbol of this part of Paris, and in recent years underwent much needed restoration that returned it to its former glory (ended in 2008). The tower is surrounded by a beautifully landscaped park, known as Square de la Tour Saint-Jacques, which offers a respite from the busy streets around it.

photo.title: Square de la Tour Saint-Jacques - (Day 17 Holiday 2011)
